verses.text: After this, Absalom the son of David had a beautiful sister whose name was Tamar, and Amnon the son of David loved her.
verses.comment: David’s complicated family relationships set the scene for this chapter’s tragic events.

verses.text: Amnon was so tormented that he made himself sick because of his sister Tamar, for she was a virgin, and it seemed impossible to Amnon to do anything to her.
verses.comment: The focus on Tamar’s virginity reflects the cultural importance of purity and family honor.

verses.text: But Amnon had a friend, whose name was Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David’s brother. Now, Jonadab was a very crafty man.
verses.comment: Jonadab’s craftiness echoes the serpent’s cunning in Genesis 3:1, hinting at the role of evil counsel in the corruption of hearts.

verses.text: He said to him, 'O son of the king, why are you so depressed morning after morning? Will you not tell me?' Amnon said to him, 'I love Tamar, my brother Absalom’s sister.'
verses.comment: Amnon’s confession reveals misplaced desire, setting up the sinful act to follow.

verses.text: Jonadab said to him, 'Lie down on your bed and pretend to be ill. When your father comes to see you, say to him, “Let my sister Tamar come and give me food to eat, and prepare the food in my sight, so that I may see it and eat from her hand.”'
verses.comment: Jonadab’s advice encourages deception and the abuse of familial trust.

verses.text: So Amnon lay down and pretended to be sick. When the king came to see him, Amnon said to the king, 'Please let my sister Tamar come and make a couple of cakes in my sight, so that I may eat from her hand.'
verses.comment: The repeated theme of deception (cf. Jacob and Esau in Genesis 27) shows the destructive consequences of sin.

verses.text: Then David sent home to Tamar, saying, 'Go to your brother Amnon’s house and prepare food for him.'
verses.comment: David, unaware of the scheme, sends Tamar, demonstrating how even righteous leaders can be misled or used for the wrong purposes.

verses.text: So Tamar went to her brother Amnon’s house, where he was lying down. She took dough, kneaded it, made cakes in his sight, and baked the cakes.
verses.comment: Tamar’s obedience and innocence heighten the tragedy about to unfold.

verses.text: She took the pan and emptied it out before him, but he refused to eat. Then Amnon said, 'Send everyone out from me.' So everyone went out from him.
verses.comment: Amnon’s intent is revealed as he removes all witnesses.

verses.text: Then Amnon said to Tamar, 'Bring the food into the bedroom, so that I may eat from your hand.' So Tamar took the cakes she had made and brought them into the bedroom to her brother Amnon.
verses.comment: The setting moves to a secluded place, underscoring the gravity of the sin about to be committed.

verses.text: But when she brought them close to him to eat, he seized her and said to her, 'Come, lie with me, my sister.'
verses.comment: Like Joseph’s temptation by Potiphar’s wife, but with tragic different results.

verses.text: She answered him, 'No, my brother, do not violate me, for such a thing is not done in Israel; do not do this disgraceful thing.'
verses.comment: Tamar’s protest invokes Israel’s moral law. Her appeal shows moral clarity in face of assault.

verses.text: As for me, where would I carry my shame? And as for you, you would be as one of the fools in Israel. Now therefore, please speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.'
verses.comment: Tamar appeals to the possibility of lawful marriage, suggesting order and blessing in following God-ordained authority.

verses.text: But he would not listen to her, and being stronger than she, he violated her and lay with her.
verses.comment: A grave sin is committed. The consequences of disordered passion and the violation of God’s law are paramount.

verses.text: Then Amnon hated her with very great hatred, so much that the hatred with which he hated her was greater than the love with which he had loved her. And Amnon said to her, 'Get up! Go!'
verses.comment: Sin corrupts love into hatred; Amnon’s desire turns instantly to rejection.

verses.text: But she said to him, 'No, because this wrong in sending me away is greater than the other that you did to me.' But he would not listen to her.
verses.comment: Tamar’s plea highlights social consequences and deepens the injustice. Law (Deut 22:29) prohibited sending her away.

verses.text: He called his young servant who attended him and said, 'Put this woman out from me, and bolt the door after her.'
verses.comment: Amnon’s callousness contrasts with Christ’s compassion toward women caught in shame.

verses.text: Now she was wearing a long robe with sleeves, for thus were the virgin daughters of the king clothed in earlier times. So his servant put her out and bolted the door after her.
verses.comment: Her royal garment underscores her innocence and the tragedy of its loss.

verses.text: Tamar put ashes on her head and tore the long robe that she wore. She laid her hand on her head and went away, crying loudly as she went.
verses.comment: Tearing of the garment and ashes signify public mourning and shame.

verses.text: Her brother Absalom said to her, 'Has Amnon your brother been with you? Now, my sister, keep silent; he is your brother. Do not take this matter to heart.' So Tamar lived, a desolate woman, in Absalom’s house.
verses.comment: Social structures failed Tamar, who is instead cared for by Absalom. The effects of sin ripple through communities.

verses.text: When King David heard of all these things, he was very angry.
verses.comment: David’s anger is recorded, but his lack of direct action will later haunt his family.

verses.text: But Absalom spoke to Amnon neither good nor bad, for Absalom hated Amnon, because he had violated his sister Tamar.
verses.comment: This silence mirrors Esau’s hatred for Jacob, foreshadowing revenge.

verses.text: After two full years, Absalom had sheep shearers at Baal-hazor, which is near Ephraim, and Absalom invited all the king’s sons.
verses.comment: Sheep shearing festivals were common times for gatherings and sometimes intrigue (see Gen 38:12).

verses.text: Absalom came to the king and said, 'Behold, your servant has sheep shearers. Please let the king and his servants go with your servant.'
verses.comment: Absalom extends an invitation appearing generous but has hidden motives.

verses.text: But the king said to Absalom, 'No, my son, let us not all go, lest we be a burden to you.' He pressed him, but he would not go, and he blessed him.
verses.comment: David’s blessing retains royal authority but shows passivity.

verses.text: Then Absalom said, 'If not, please let my brother Amnon go with us.' And the king said to him, 'Why should he go with you?'
verses.comment: David senses something is amiss, but ultimately he allows it.

verses.text: But Absalom pressed him until he let Amnon and all the king’s sons go with him.
verses.comment: Persistence wins, and the king’s restraint is ultimately passive consent.

verses.text: Then Absalom commanded his servants, 'Mark when Amnon’s heart is merry with wine, and when I say to you, “Strike Amnon,” then kill him. Do not fear; have I not commanded you? Be courageous and do it.'
verses.comment: Absalom’s command echoes other biblical accounts of revenge killings, showing sin begetting further sin.

verses.text: So the servants of Absalom did to Amnon just as Absalom had commanded. Then all the king’s sons arose, and each mounted his mule and fled.
verses.comment: Fear spreads; violence among brethren divides the royal family.

verses.text: While they were on their way, a report came to David, 'Absalom has struck down all the king’s sons, and not one of them is left.'
verses.comment: The first news exaggerates the tragedy, a common reaction in crisis.

verses.text: Then the king arose and tore his garments and lay on the ground; all his servants who stood by tore their garments as well.
verses.comment: David and his court grieve deeply. Tearing garments is a sign of mourning (see Job 1:20).

verses.text: But Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David’s brother, said, 'Let not my lord suppose that they have killed all the young men, the king’s sons, for Amnon alone is dead. This has been determined by Absalom since the day he violated his sister Tamar.'
verses.comment: Jonadab, though crafty, clarifies the situation—revealing hidden intentions known to some in David’s court.

verses.text: Now therefore, let not my lord the king take this thing to heart, thinking all the king’s sons are dead, for only Amnon is dead.
verses.comment: Jonadab reduces the scale of the tragedy to manageable proportions.

verses.text: But Absalom fled. And the young man who kept the watch lifted up his eyes and looked, and there were many people coming from the road behind him by the side of the mountain.
verses.comment: Absalom’s flight marks the beginning of further divisions in David’s kingdom.

verses.text: Jonadab said to the king, 'Behold, the king’s sons have come; as your servant said, so it has come about.'
verses.comment: Jonadab’s report is confirmed; not all is lost.

verses.text: As soon as he had finished speaking, the king’s sons came and lifted up their voices and wept. The king and all his servants wept very bitterly also.
verses.comment: Weeping together expresses communal sorrow, showing the deep wounds sin causes in relationships.

verses.text: Absalom fled and went to Talmai the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. And David mourned for his son day after day.
verses.comment: Absalom seeks asylum with his maternal grandfather; David’s grief demonstrates ongoing consequences of unresolved sin.

verses.text: So Absalom fled and went to Geshur, and was there for three years.
verses.comment: Three years of exile parallel other notable biblical exiles (cf. Moses, Christ’s three days in the tomb).

verses.text: And the spirit of the king longed to go out to Absalom, for he was comforted concerning Amnon, since he was dead.
verses.comment: David’s paternal heart yearns for mercy and reconciliation, themes fulfilled when the true Messiah heals even deeper familial wounds (cf. Luke 15:20).
